text.headline: Early Evolutionary and Developmental Processes
text.text: Evolution of sex differentiation and gendered behaviours.

text.headline: Emergence of Primates
text.text: Early primates developed distinctive traits and social behaviours, enhancing visual acuity and grasping abilities, setting the stage for complex social interactions and gender roles (Ni et al., 2013).

text.headline: Early Primates Social Structures
text.text: Early primates developed rudimentary social structures with gender-specific roles, likely centred around reproduction and resource acquisition; inferred from modern primate behaviours (Gingerich, 2006).

text.headline: Gender Segregation in Early Primates
text.text: Gender segregation emerged with differing roles, likely in foraging and child-rearing; optimizing survival and reproductive success through specialization (Lovejoy, 1981).

text.headline: Sexual Selection Shaping Traits
text.text: Sexual selection played a pivotal role in shaping physical and behavioural traits in primates. Driven by the pressures of mate competition and selection, traits such as body size and mating behaviours began to diverge significantly between genders (Plavcan, 2002).

text.headline: Genetic Basis of Gender Traits
text.text: By this point, the genetic basis of gender-specific traits had become more pronounced in primates. Genetic differences in hormone regulation and reproductive anatomy influenced gender-specific traits, impacting social behaviours and reproductive strategies (Del Giudice, 2009).

text.headline: Impact of Environmental Changes
text.text: Environmental changes prompted adaptations in social structures and reproductive strategies. These evolutionary pressures reinforced gender-specific roles and contributed to the diversification of primate species (Janzen & Phillips, 2006).

text.headline: Tool Use, Bipedalism, and Gender-Specific Tasks
text.text: Tool use and bipedalism introduced new dimensions to gender-specific tasks, with males focusing on hunting and tool-making and females on gathering and child care (Lovejoy, 1981).
